**Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates**
Managements Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations is based upon our consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States. The preparation of these financial statements requires us to make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, sales and expenses, and related disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities. We base our estimates on historical experience and on various other assumptions that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, the results of which form the basis for making judgments about the carrying values of assets and liabilities that are not readily apparent from other sources. Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions. For a detailed discussion of our critical accounting policies, please refer to our annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2014 filed with the SEC on April 2, 2015. Our critical accounting policies and estimates did not change materially during the three months ended March 31, 2015.
**_Recent Accounting Pronouncements._** See Note 1Organization and Summary of Significant Accounting Policies in the accompanying notes to the condensed consolidated financial statements for recently adopted and issued accounting pronouncements.
**
## ITEM 3. Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
**
**Interest Rate Risk**
We centrally manage our debt and investment portfolios considering investment opportunities and risks, tax consequences and overall financing strategies. Our exposure to market risk includes interest rate fluctuations in connection with our revolving credit facility and certain financial instruments. In addition to the revolving credit facility, we have incurred short- and long-term indebtedness related to the implementation of our ERP system. Borrowings under these debt instruments bear fixed interest rates and therefore, do not have the potential for market risk.
Borrowings under the revolving credit facility bear interest at a variable rate. For domestic rate loans, the interest rate is equal to the highest of (i) the daily federal funds open rate as quoted by ICAP North America, Inc. plus 0.5%, (ii) PNCs prime rate and (iii) a daily LIBOR rate plus 1.0%, in each case there is an additional margin ranging from 0.25% to 1.00% based on certain conditions. For LIBOR rate loans, the interest rate is equal to a LIBOR rate plus a margin ranging from 1.25% to 2.00% based on certain conditions. Borrowings under the revolving credit facility are therefore subject to risk based upon prevailing market interest rates. Interest rates fluctuate as a result of many factors, including governmental monetary and tax policies, domestic and international economic and political considerations and other factors that are beyond our control. As of March 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014, there were no borrowings under the revolving credit facility.
We additionally hold cash equivalents including certificate of deposits, time deposits and money market funds. Interest income generated from these cash equivalents will fluctuate with the general level of interest rates. As of March 31, 2015, we held $13.0 million in cash equivalents subject to variable interest rates. If the prevailing market interest rates relative to these investments increased or decreased by 10% during the three months ended March 31, 2015, interest income would have increased or decreased by a negligible amount.
**Foreign Currency Exchange Risk**
As a global company, we have significant revenues and costs denominated in currencies other than the U.S. Dollar. We pay the majority of expenses attributable to our foreign operations in the functional currency of the country in which such operations are conducted and pay the majority of our overseas third-party manufacturers in U.S. Dollars. Our ability to sell our products in foreign markets and the U.S. Dollar value of the sales made in foreign currencies can be significantly influenced by foreign currency fluctuations. Fluctuations in the value of foreign currencies relative to the U.S. Dollar could result in downward price pressure for our products and increase losses from currency exchange rates. An increase or decrease of 1% in value of the U.S. Dollar relative to foreign currencies would have increased or decreased loss before taxes for the three months ended March 31, 2015 by approximately $0.9 million. The volatility of the applicable exchange rates is dependent on many factors that cannot be forecasted with reliable accuracy. In the event our foreign sales and purchases increase and are denominated in currencies other than the U.S. Dollar, our operating results may be affected by fluctuations in the exchange rate of currencies we receive for such sales. See Item 2, Managements Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations, for a discussion of the impact of foreign exchange rate variances experienced for the three months ended March 31, 2015 and 2014.
31
* * *


Table of Contents
We transact business in various foreign countries and are therefore exposed to foreign currency exchange rate risk inherent in revenues, costs, and monetary assets and liabilities denominated in non-functional currencies. We have entered into foreign currency exchange forward contracts and currency swap derivative instruments to selectively protect against volatility in the value of non-functional currency denominated monetary assets and liabilities, and of future cash flows caused by changes in foreign currency exchange rates.
The following table summarizes the notional amounts of the outstanding foreign currency exchange contracts as of March 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014. The notional amounts of the derivative financial instruments shown below are denominated in their U.S. Dollar equivalents and represent the amount of all contracts of the foreign currency specified. These notional values do not necessarily represent amounts exchanged by the parties and, therefore, are not a direct measure of our exposure to the foreign currency exchange risks.

## ITEM 4. Controls and Procedures
**
**Evaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures**
Under the supervision of and with the participation of our senior management, including our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, we conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of the design and operation of our disclosure controls and procedures, as defined in Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Exchange Act, as of March 31, 2015 (the Evaluation Date). Based on this evaluation, our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer concluded that as of the Evaluation Date, our disclosure controls and procedures were effective, such that the information relating to us, including our consolidated subsidiaries, required to be disclosed in our Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) reports (i) is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in SEC rules and forms, and (ii) is accumulated and communicated to our management, including our Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, as appropriate to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure.
**Changes in Internal Control over Financial Reporting**
There have been no changes to our internal control over financial reporting during the three months ended March 31, 2015 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, our internal control over financial reporting, other than certain changes and improvements to our processes and procedures resulting from our implementation of our new ERP system.

**PART II  Other Information**
**
## Item 1. Legal Proceedings
**
We are currently subject to an audit by U.S. Customs & Border Protection (CBP) in respect of the period from 2006 to 2010. In October 2013, CBP issued the final audit report. In that report CBP projects that unpaid duties totaling approximately $12.4 million are due for the period under review and recommended collection of the duties due. We responded that these projections are erroneous and provided arguments that demonstrate the amount due in connection with this matter is considerably less than the projection. Additionally, on December 12, 2014, we made an offer to settle CBPs potential claims and tendered $3.5 million. At this time, it is not possible to determine how long it will take CBP to evaluate our offer or to predict whether our offer will be accepted. Likewise, if a settlement cannot be reached, it is not possible to predict with any certainty whether CBP will seek to assert a claim for penalties in addition to any unpaid duties, but such an assertion is a possibility.
Mexicos Federal Tax Authority (SAT) has audited our records regarding imports and exports during the period from January 2006 to July 2011. There were two phases to the audit, the first for capital equipment and finished goods and the second for raw materials. The first phase was completed and no major discrepancies were noted by the SAT. On January 9, 2013, we received a notice for the second phase in which the SAT issued a tax assessment (taxes and penalties) of roughly 280.0 million pesos (approximately $22.0 million) based on the value of all of our imported raw materials during the audit period. We believe that the proposed penalty amount is unfounded and without merit. With the help of local counsel we filed an appeal by the deadline of March 15, 2013. We have argued that the amount due in connection with the matter, if any, is substantially less than that proposed by the SAT. In connection with the appeal, the SAT required us to post an appeal surety bond in the amount of roughly 321.0 million pesos (approximately $26.0 million), which amount reflects estimated additional penalties and interest if we are not successful on our appeal. This amount will be adjusted on an annual basis. On November 27, 2014, the Superior Chamber of the Federal Tax Court ruled in our favor and annulled the tax assessment and the corresponding penalty. The SAT filed its appeal of the decision in our favor on February 25, 2015. The parties are currently awaiting a ruling on the appeal. It is not possible at this time to predict the outcome of this matter or reasonably estimate any potential loss.
We are currently subject to an audit by the Brazilian Federal Tax Authorities related to imports of footwear from China between 2010 to 2014. On January 13, 2015 we were notified about the issuance of assessments totaling roughly $5.25 million for the period January 2010 through May 2011. We have disputed these assessments and asserted defenses to the claims. On February 25, 2015, we received additional assessments totaling roughly $11.54 million related to the remainder of the audit period. We have also disputed these assessments and asserted defenses to these claims. It is not possible at this time to predict the outcome of this matter, therefore, we have no accrual for this matter as of March 31, 2015.
On August 8, 2014, a purported class action lawsuit was filed in California state court against our subsidiary, Crocs Retail, LLC, Zaydenberg v. Crocs Retail, LLC, Case No. BC554214. The lawsuit alleges various employment law violations related to overtime, meal and break periods, minimum wage, timely payment of wages, wage statements, payroll records and business expenses. We filed an answer on February 6, 2015, denying the allegations and asserting several defenses. The parties are exchanging documents and information relevant to the issue of class certification and plan to participate in mediation in June 2015. It is not possible at this time to predict the outcome of this matter or reasonably estimate any potential loss.
Although we are subject to other litigation from time to time in the ordinary course of business, including employment, intellectual property and product liability claims, we are not party to any other pending legal proceedings that we believe would reasonably have a material adverse impact on our business, financial position, results of operations or cash flows.
33

**

* * *
(1) On December 26, 2013, the board of directors approved the repurchase of up to $350.0 million of our common stock, which was announced on December 30, 2013. During the three months ended March 31, 2015, we repurchased approximately 1.7 million shares at a weighted-average price of $11.60 for an aggregate price of approximately $20.0 million excluding related commission charges, under our publicly-announced repurchase plan. As of March 31, 2015, approximately $182.1 million of shares remained available for repurchase under our share repurchase authorization. The number, price, structure and timing of the repurchases, if any, will be at our sole discretion and future repurchases will be evaluated by us depending on market conditions, liquidity needs and other factors. Share repurchases may be made in the open market or in privately negotiated transactions. The repurchase authorization does not have an expiration date and does not oblige us to acquire any particular amount of our common stock. The board of directors may suspend, modify or terminate the repurchase program at any time without prior notice.

EX-31.1 2 a15-7898_1ex31d1.htm EX-31.1
**EXHIBIT 31.1**
**SECTION 302 CERTIFICATION**
I, Gregg Ribatt, certify that:
1. I have reviewed this annual report on Form 10-Q of Crocs, Inc.;
2. Based on my knowledge, this report does not contain any untrue statement of a material fact or omit to state a material fact necessary to make the statements made, in light of the circumstances under which such statements were made, not misleading with respect to the period covered by this report;
3. Based on my knowledge, the financial statements, and other financial information included in this report, fairly present in all material respects the financial condition, results of operations and cash flows of the registrant as of, and for, the periods presented in this report;
4. The registrants other certifying officer(s) and I are responsible for establishing and maintaining disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e)) and internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f)) for the registrant and have:
(a) Designed such disclosure controls and procedures, or caused such disclosure controls and procedures to be designed under our supervision, to ensure that material information relating to the registrant, including its consolidated subsidiaries, is made known to us by others within those entities, particularly during the period in which this report is being prepared;
(b) Designed such internal control over financial reporting, or caused such internal control over financial reporting to be designed under our supervision, to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles;
(c) Evaluated the effectiveness of the registrants disclosure controls and procedures and presented in this report our conclusions about the effectiveness of the disclosure controls and procedures, as of the end of the period covered by this report based on such evaluation; and
(d) Disclosed in this report any change in the registrants internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the registrants most recent fiscal quarter (the registrants fourth fiscal quarter in the case of an annual report) that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, the registrants internal control over financial reporting; and
5. The registrants other certifying officer(s) and I have disclosed, based on our most recent evaluation of internal control over financial reporting, to the registrants auditors and the audit committee of the registrants board of directors (or persons performing the equivalent functions):
(a) All significant deficiencies and material weaknesses in the design or operation of internal control over financial reporting which are reasonably likely to adversely affect the registrants ability to record, process, summarize and report financial information; and
(b) Any fraud, whether or not material, that involves management or other employees who have a significant role in the registrants internal control over financial reporting.
Date: May 8, 2015
/s/ Gregg Ribatt
Gregg Ribatt

**SECTION 302 CERTIFICATION**
I, Jeffrey J. Lasher, certify that:
1. I have reviewed this annual report on Form 10-Q of Crocs, Inc.;
2. Based on my knowledge, this report does not contain any untrue statement of a material fact or omit to state a material fact necessary to make the statements made, in light of the circumstances under which such statements were made, not misleading with respect to the period covered by this report;
3. Based on my knowledge, the financial statements, and other financial information included in this report, fairly present in all material respects the financial condition, results of operations and cash flows of the registrant as of, and for, the periods presented in this report;
4. The registrants other certifying officer(s) and I are responsible for establishing and maintaining disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e)) and internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f)) for the registrant and have:
(a) Designed such disclosure controls and procedures, or caused such disclosure controls and procedures to be designed under our supervision, to ensure that material information relating to the registrant, including its consolidated subsidiaries, is made known to us by others within those entities, particularly during the period in which this report is being prepared;
(b) Designed such internal control over financial reporting, or caused such internal control over financial reporting to be designed under our supervision, to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles;
(c) Evaluated the effectiveness of the registrants disclosure controls and procedures and presented in this report our conclusions about the effectiveness of the disclosure controls and procedures, as of the end of the period covered by this report based on such evaluation; and
(d) Disclosed in this report any change in the registrants internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the registrants most recent fiscal quarter (the registrants fourth fiscal quarter in the case of an annual report) that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, the registrants internal control over financial reporting; and
5. The registrants other certifying officer(s) and I have disclosed, based on our most recent evaluation of internal control over financial reporting, to the registrants auditors and the audit committee of the registrants board of directors (or persons performing the equivalent functions):
(a) All significant deficiencies and material weaknesses in the design or operation of internal control over financial reporting which are reasonably likely to adversely affect the registrants ability to record, process, summarize and report financial information; and
(b) Any fraud, whether or not material, that involves management or other employees who have a significant role in the registrants internal control over financial reporting.

(2) The information contained in the Form 10-Q fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Company for the period covered by this Form 10-Q.

15800000 0.0375 0.0125 0.0115 2400000 1000000 6200000 12110000 15884000 100000000 50000000 4100000 0.050 0.050 5250000.00000 11540000.00000 177507000 177625000 2000000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">1</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">5</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">. LEGAL PROCEEDINGS</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We are currently subject to an audit by U.S. Customs &amp; Border Protection (&#x201C;CBP&#x201D;) in respect of</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> the period from 2006 to 2010. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">In October 2013, CBP</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> issued the final audit report. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">In that report CBP projects that unpaid duties totaling approximately </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">12.4</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">million are due for the pe</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">riod under review and recommended collection of the duties due. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We responded that these projections are erroneous and provided arguments that demonstrate the amount due in connection with this matter is consider</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ably less than the projection.&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Additionally, on December 12, 2014, we made an offer to settle CBP&#x2019;s potential cla</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ims and tendered </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$3.5</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">At this time, it is not possible to determine how long it will take CBP to evaluate our offer or to predict wheth</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">er our offer will be accepted. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Likewise, if a settlement cannot be reached, it is not possible to predict with any certainty whether CBP will seek to assert a claim for penalties in addition to any unpaid duties, but such an assertion is a possibility.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Mexico&#x2019;s Federal Tax Authority (&#x201C;SAT&#x201D;) has audited </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">our</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> records regarding imports and exports during the period f</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">rom January 2006 to July 2011.&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">There were two phases to the audit, the first for capital equipment and finished goods and the seco</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">nd for raw materials.&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">The first phase was completed and no major discre</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">pancies were noted by the SAT.&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">On January 9, 2013, Crocs received a notice for the second phase in which the SAT issued a tax assessment (taxes and penalties) of roughly </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">280.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">million pesos (approximately </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">22.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">million) based on the value of all of Crocs&#x2019; imported raw mate</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">rials during the audit period.&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We believe that the proposed penalty amount</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> is unfounded and without merit. With the help of local counsel we filed an appeal by the d</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">eadline of March 15, 2013.&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We have argued that the amount due in connection with the matter, if any, is substantially less </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">than that proposed by the SAT.&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">In connection with the appeal, the SAT required us to post an appeal surety bond in the amount of roughly </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">321.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">million pesos (approximately </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">26.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">million), which amount reflects estimated additional penalties and interest if we are not successful on our appeal.&nbsp; This amount will </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">be adjusted on an annual basis. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">On November 27, 2014, the Superior Chamber of the Federal Tax Court ruled in favor of Crocs and annulled the tax assessment </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">and the corresponding penalty.&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">The SAT filed its appeal of the decision in Crocs&#x2019; favor on February 25, 2015. The parties are currently awaiting a ruling on the appeal.&nbsp;&nbsp;It is not possible at this time to predict the outcome of this matter or reasonably estimate any potential loss.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Crocs is currently subject to an audit by the Brazilian Federal Tax Authorities related to imports of footwear</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> from China between 2010-2014. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">On January 13, 2015 Crocs was notified about the issuance of assessments totaling roughly </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$5.25 </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">million for the period </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">January 2010 through May 2011. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Crocs has disputed these assessments and as</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">serted defenses to the claims. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">On February 25, 201</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">5, </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Crocs received additional assessments totaling roughly </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$11.54 </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">million related to the remainder of the audit period.&nbsp;&nbsp;Crocs has also disputed these assessments and asserted defenses to these claims.&nbsp;&nbsp;It is not possible at this time to pre</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">dict the outcome of this matter, therefore, we have </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">no</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> accrual for this matter as of March 31, 2015.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">On August 8, 2014, a purported class action lawsuit was filed in California state court against our subsidiary, Crocs Retail, LLC, Zaydenberg v. Crocs Retail, LLC, Case No. BC554214. The lawsuit alleges various employment law violations related to overtime, meal and break periods, minimum wage, timely payment of wages, wage statements, payroll records and business expenses. We filed an answer on February 6, 2015, denying the allegations and asserting several defenses. The parties are exchanging documents and information relevant to the issue of class certification and plan to participate in mediation in June 2015. It is not possible at this time to predict the outcome of this matter or reasonably estimate any potential loss.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">As of March 31, 2015, we have accrued a total of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">4.2</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million relating to these litigation matters and other disputes. We estimate that the ultimate resolution of these litigation matters and other disputes could result in a loss that is reasonably possible between </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$0.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">million and </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">9.8 </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">million in the aggregate, in excess of the amount accrued.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Although</font><font style="display: inline;"> we are subject to other litigation from time to time in the ordinary course of business, including employment, intellectual property and product liability claims, we are not party to any other pending legal proceedings that we believe would reasonably have a material adverse impact on our business, financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 20000000 0.0100 182200000 5088000 68000 5 9 9 267512000 180698000 94662000 -86814000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">13.</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;"> COMMITMENTS AND CONTINGENCIES</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Rental Commitments and Contingencies</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt 12pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">We rent space for our retail stores, offices, warehouses, vehicles, and equipment under operating leases expiring at various dates through 2033. Certain leases contain rent escalation clauses (step rents) that require additional rental amounts in the later years of the term. Rent expense for leases with step rents or rent holidays is recognized on a straight-line basis over the lease term beginning on the lease inception date. Deferred rent is included in the </font><font style="display: inline;">condensed consolidated</font><font style="display: inline;"> balance sheets in &#x2018;Accrued expenses and other current liabilities</font><font style="display: inline;">.&#x2019;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;color:#252525;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> <p </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We are regularly subject to, and are currently undergoing, audits by tax authorities in the United States and several foreign jurisdictions for prior tax years.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">In April&nbsp;2013, Brazil&#x2019;s State of Sao Paulo, Brazil government (&#x201C;Brazil&#x201D;) assessed sales taxes, interest and penalties for the period April&nbsp;2009 to May&nbsp;2011.&nbsp;We had previously tendered these taxes using Brazil obligations purchased at a discount from third parties. On&nbsp;May&nbsp;22, 2013, we&nbsp;applied for amnesty in order to receive a significant reduction in penalties and interest, agreed to amend our 2009&nbsp;through&nbsp;2012&nbsp;tax returns to remove the Brazil obligations, and agreed to settle the assessment in cash to Brazil. In June&nbsp;2013, </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">we made a </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">cash payment to Brazil, in full satisfaction of the Brazil assessment and amended tax returns. </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">While </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Brazil is&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">currently </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> the </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">entire carrying balance of the </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">Brazil </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">obligation</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> as we determined the ultimate collection of amounts due is not assured</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Basis of Presentation</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-style:italic;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The accompanying unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States (&#x201C;GAAP&#x201D;) for interim financial information and with the rules&nbsp;and regulations of the Securities and Exchange Commission (&#x201C;SEC&#x201D;) for reporting on Form&nbsp;10-Q. The condensed consolidated balance sheet as of December 31, 2014 was derived from the Company&#x2019;s Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2014 (the &#x201C;2014 Form 10-K&#x201D;) but does not include all disclosures required by GAAP. The accompanying unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements and these notes thereto should be read in conjunction with the 2014 Form 10-K. In the opinion of management, these financial statements reflect all adjustments (consisting solely of normal recurring matters) considered necessary for a fair statement of the results for the interim periods presented. The results of operations for any interim period are not necessarily indicative of results for the full year.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 156202000 134823000 1300000 1400000 500000 600000 3075000 3545000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">8</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">. &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">REVOLVING CREDIT FACILITY &amp; </font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">BANK BORROWINGS</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt 12pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Revolving Credit Facility</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">On September 25, 2009, we entered into a Revolving Credit and Security Agreement (the &#x201C;Credit Agreement&#x201D;) with the lenders named therein and PNC Bank, National Association ("PNC"), as a lender and administrative agent for the lenders. </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">On April 2, 2015, we entered into the Sixth Amendment to Amended and Restated Credit Agreement (the &#x201C;Sixth Amendment&#x201D;), pursuant to which certain terms of the Credit Agreement were amended. The Sixth Amendment primarily amended certain definitions of the financial covenants to become more favorable to us including (i) setting the minimum fixed charge coverage ratio to </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">1.00</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> to 1.00 through December 31, 2015, </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">1.15</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> to 1.00 through March 31, 2016 and </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">1.25</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> to 1.00 for each</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> quarter thereafter, (ii)&nbsp;s</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">etting the Leverage Ratio to </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">4.00</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> to 1.00 through March 31, 2016 and </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">3.75</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> to 1.00 f</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">or each quarter thereafter and&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">(iii) reducing our global cash requirement from </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$100</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million to </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$50</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The Credit Agreement enables us to borrow up </font><font style="display: inline;">to </font><font style="display: inline;">$100.0</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, with the abilit</font><font style="display: inline;">y to increase commitments </font><font style="display: inline;">to </font><font style="display: inline;">$125.0</font><font style="display: inline;"> million</font><font style="display: inline;"> subject to certain conditions, and is currently set </font><font style="display: inline;">to mature in </font><font style="display: inline;">December 2017</font><font style="display: inline;">. The Credit Agreement is available for working capital, capital expenditures, permitted acquisitions, reimbursement of drawings under letters of credit, and permitted dividends, distributions, purchases, redemptions and retirements of equity </font><font style="display: inline;">interests. Borrowings under the Credit Agreement are secured by all of our assets including all receivables, equipment, general intangibles, inventory, investment property, subsidiary stock and intellectual property. Borrowings under the Credit Agreement bear interest at a variable rate</font><font style="display: inline;">. For domestic rate loans, the interest rate is equal to the highest of (i) the daily federal funds open rate as quoted by ICAP North America, Inc. plus </font><font style="display: inline;">0.5%</font><font style="display: inline;">, (ii) PNC's prime rate and (iii) a daily LIBOR rate plus </font><font style="display: inline;">1.0%</font><font style="display: inline;">, in each case there is an additional margin ranging from </font><font style="display: inline;">0.25%</font><font style="display: inline;"> to </font><font style="display: inline;">1.00%</font><font style="display: inline;"> based on certain conditions. For LIBOR rate loans, the interest rate is equal to a LIBOR rate plus a margin ranging from </font><font style="display: inline;">1.25%</font><font style="display: inline;"> to </font><font style="display: inline;">2.00%</font><font style="display: inline;"> based on certain conditions. The Credit Agreement requires monthly interest payments with respect to domestic rate loans and at the end of each interest period with respect to LIBOR rate loans. The Credit Agreement further provides for a limit on the issuance of letters of credit to a maximum </font><font style="display: inline;">of </font><font style="display: inline;">$20.0</font><font style="display: inline;"> million</font><font style="display: inline;">. The Credit Agreement contains provisions requiring us to maintain compliance with certain restrictive and financial covenants. As of March 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014, the fair value of our debt instruments approximates their reported carrying amounts. </font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">As of </font><font style="display: inline;">March</font><font style="display: inline;"> 31, 201</font><font style="display: inline;">5</font><font style="display: inline;"> and </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, </font><font style="display: inline;">201</font><font style="display: inline;">4</font><font style="display: inline;">, we had </font><font style="display: inline;">no</font><font style="display: inline;"> outstanding borrowings under the Credit Agreement. As of </font><font style="display: inline;">March </font><font style="display: inline;">31, 201</font><font style="display: inline;">5</font><font style="display: inline;"> and </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, </font><font style="display: inline;">201</font><font style="display: inline;">4</font><font style="display: inline;">, we had issued and outstanding letters of </font><font style="display: inline;">credit of </font><font style="display: inline;">$</font><font style="display: inline;">1.7</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">$1.8</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, respectively, which were reserved against the borrowing base under the terms of the Credit Agreement</font><font style="display: inline;">. As of March 31, 2015, we were in compliance with all restrictive financial and other covenants under the Credit Agreement.</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New Roman;;font-size: 10pt"><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;"></font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Lo</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">ng-term Bank Borrowings</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">On December 10, 2012, we entered into a Master Installment Payment Agreement (&#x201C;Master IPA&#x201D;) with PNC in which PNC finances our purchase of software and services, which may include but are not limited to third party costs to design, install and implement software systems, and associated hardware described in the schedules defined within the Master IPA. The Master IPA was entered into to finance our implementation of a new enterprise resource planning (&#x201C;ERP&#x201D;) system, which began in October 2012 and was substantially completed in early 2015. The terms of each note payable under the Master IPA consist of variable interest rates and payment terms based on amounts borrowed and timing of activity throughout the implementation of the ERP system.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">As of </font><font style="display: inline;">March</font><font style="display: inline;"> 31, 201</font><font style="display: inline;">5</font><font style="display: inline;"> and </font><font style="display: inline;">December 31, </font><font style="display: inline;">201</font><font style="display: inline;">4</font><font style="display: inline;">, we had </font><font style="display: inline;">$10.3</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$11.6</font><font style="display: inline;"> million</font><font style="display: inline;">, respectively, of</font><font style="display: inline;"> debt outstanding under </font><font style="display: inline;">five</font><font style="display: inline;"> separate notes payable, </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">of which </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">$5.3</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> million </font><font style="display: inline;">represent</font><font style="display: inline;">s &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">current installments</font><font style="display: inline;"> for both periods</font><font style="display: inline;">. As of </font><font style="display: inline;">March</font><font style="display: inline;"> 31, 201</font><font style="display: inline;">5</font><font style="display: inline;">, the notes bear interest rates ranging from </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">2.45%</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> to </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">2.79%</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">and maturities ranging from </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">September 2016</font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;"> to </font><font style="display: inline;color:#000000;">September 2017</font><font style="display: inline;">. As this debt arrangement relates solely to the construction and implementation of an ERP system for use by the entity, interest expense </font><font style="display: inline;">was</font><font style="display: inline;"> capitalized to the condensed consolidated balance sheets until the assets </font><font style="display: inline;">were placed into service on January 1, 2015. </font><font style="display: inline;">During the </font><font style="display: inline;">three months</font><font style="display: inline;"> ended </font><font style="display: inline;">March</font><font style="display: inline;"> 31, 201</font><font style="display: inline;">5, </font><font style="display: inline;">no</font><font style="display: inline;"> interest was capitalized. During the three months ended March 31,</font><font style="display: inline;"> 201</font><font style="display: inline;">4</font><font style="display: inline;">, we capitalized </font><font style="display: inline;">$0.1</font><font style="display: inline;"> million in interest expense related to this debt arrangement to the condensed consolidated balance sheets. Interest rates and payment terms are subject to changes as further financing occurs under the Master IPA.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 0.005 0.010 0.0100 0.0025 0.0200 0.0125 0.0279 0.0245 2017-12-01 2017-09-01 2016-09-01 4190000 3971000 17886000 17536000 11869000 11853000 5400000 4700000 9373000 1599000 2684000 5090000 2448000 1740000 902000 9719000 1987000 3742000 3990000 1974000 1213000 803000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Depreciation and Amortization</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">During the three months ended March 31, 2015 and 2014, we recorded </font><font style="display: inline;">$4.7</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$5.4</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million, respectively, in depreciation expense of which </font><font style="display: inline;">$0.6</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$0.5</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million, respectively, was recorded in &#x2018;Cost of sales,&#x2019; with the remaining amounts recorded in &#x2018;Selling, general and administrative expenses&#x2019; on the condensed consolidated statements of operations. As of March 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014, accumulated depreciation was </font><font style="display: inline;">$106.1</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$99.8</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, respectively.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 319639000 17230000 5376000 134755000 3005000 814000 44533000 7913000 3356000 13180000 3229000 743000 917000 1838000 61887000 4355000 14590000 1918000 275208000 1005000 20931000 4352000 26924000 3474000 1892000 93301000 5747000 4919000 12923000 2494000 709000 2876000 59843000 7023000 25223000 1572000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 12pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-size:12pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 12pt"> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;;font-size: 12pt"><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-size:12pt;"></font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">7</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">. DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt 18pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We transact business in various foreign countries and are therefore exposed to foreign currency exchange rate risk inherent in revenues, costs, and monetary assets and liabilities denominated in non-functional currencies. We </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">have </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">enter</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ed</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> into foreign currency exchange forward contract</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> and currency swap derivative instruments </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">to selectively protect against volatility in the value of non-functional currency denominated monetary assets and liabilities, and of future cash flows caused by changes in foreig</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">n currency exchange rates. We do not designate these</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">derivative instruments</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> as hedging instruments under the accounting standards for derivatives and hedging.</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> Accordingly, these instruments are recorded at fair value as a derivative asset or liability on the balance sheet with their corresponding change in fair value </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">recognized in &#x2018;Foreign currency transaction </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">gain (loss)</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">, net&#x2019; in our </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">condensed consolidated statements of operations. For purposes of the cash flow statement, we classify</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> the cash flows at settlement from undesignated instruments in the same category as the cash flows from the related hedged </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">items, generally with</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">in &#x2018;Cash provided by operating activities</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">.&#x2019;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">The following table summarizes the notional amounts of the outstanding foreign cur</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">rency exchange contracts as of March 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">. The notional amounts of the derivative financial instruments shown below</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> are denominated in their U.S. D</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ollar equivalents and represent the amount of all contracts of the foreign currency specified. These notional values do not necessarily represent amounts exchanged by the parties and, therefore, are not a direct measure of our exposure to the foreign currency exchange risks.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 1pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:1pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">The account &#x2018;Foreign currency transaction </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">gain (loss), ne</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">t&#x2019; on the condensed consolidated statements of operations includes both realized and unrealized gains/losses from underlying foreign currency activity and derivative contracts. These gains and losses are reported on a net basis. For the three months ended March 31, 2015, the net </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">gain </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">recognized of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$0.5</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million recorded on the condensed </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">consolidated statements of operations was comprised of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">a &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$6</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">.2</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million net gain associated with exposure from day-to-day business transactions in various foreign currencies</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> and</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">a &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$5.7</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million net loss associated wit</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">h our derivative instruments</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">. For the three</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> months ended March 31, 2014, the net loss recognized of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$2.8</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million recorded on the condensed consolidated statements of operations was comprised of a </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$1.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million net loss associated with exposure from day-to-day business transactions in various foreign currencies.</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">9</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">. &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">STOCK-BASED COMPENSATION</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> compensation expense is based on the grant date fair value and is recognized on a straight-line basis over the applicable vesting period. </font><font style="display: inline;">During the </font><font system for use by the entity, was capitalized to the condensed consolidated balance sheets.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt;font-family:Times New 18pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The total grant date fair value of RSAs vested during the </font><font style="display: inline;">three months</font><font style="display: inline;"> ended </font><font style="display: inline;">March 31</font><font style="display: inline;">, 201</font><font style="display: inline;">5 &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">was </font><font style="display: inline;">$0.1</font><font style="display: inline;"> million. As</font><font style="display: inline;"> of </font><font style="display: inline;">March</font><font style="display: inline;"> 31, 201</font><font style="display: inline;">5</font><font style="display: inline;">, we had </font><font style="display: inline;">$29</font><font style="display: inline;">.2</font><font style="display: inline;"> thousand o</font><font style="display: inline;">f total unrecognized share-based compensation expense related to non-vested restricted stock awards, net of expected forfeitures, all of which was related to time-based awards. The unvested RSAs are expected to be amortized over the remaining weighted-average </font><font style="display: inline;">period of </font><font style="display: inline;">0.19</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;years.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The total grant date fair value of RSUs vested during the </font><font style="display: inline;">three months</font><font style="display: inline;"> ended </font><font style="display: inline;">March</font><font style="display: inline;"> 31, 201</font><font style="display: inline;">5 &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">was </font><font style="display: inline;">$6.5</font><font style="display: inline;"> million. As of </font><font style="display: inline;">March</font><font style="display: inline;"> 31, 201</font><font style="display: inline;">5</font><font style="display: inline;">, we </font><font style="display: inline;">had </font><font style="display: inline;">$20.3</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;million of</font><font style="display: inline;"> total unrecognized share-based compensation expense related to unvested restricted stock units, net of expected forfeitures, of </font><font style="display: inline;">which </font><font style="display: inline;">$11.5</font><font style="display: inline;"> million is related to time-based awards and </font><font style="display: inline;">$8.8</font><font style="display: inline;"> million is related</font><font style="display: inline;"> to performance-based awards</font><font style="display: inline;">. The unvested RSUs are expected to be amortized over the remaining weighted-average period of </font><font style="display: inline;">2.42</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;years, which consists of a remaining weighted-average period of </font><font style="display: inline;">2.47</font><font style="display: inline;"> years related to performance-based awards and a remaining weighted-average period of </font><font style="display: inline;">2.20</font><font style="display: inline;"> years related to time-based awards.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Appointment of CEO</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;text-indent: -18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 12pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">On December 12, 2014, Gregg Ribatt was appointed </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">as </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">our Chief Executive Office</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">r, effective January 28, 2015. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">In connection with his appointment as Chief Executive Officer, Mr. Ribatt was granted a sign-on time-vesting RSU award representing the right to receive shares of our common stock equal to </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$2.0 </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">million</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">, based on a </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">30</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">-day weighted-average stock price as of December 15, 2014. This time-vesting RSU award will vest in three annual installments beginning on the first anniversary of his start date, subject to his continued employment with us as of each vesting date. In addition, Mr. Ribatt was granted a sign-on performance-vesting RSU award, subject to various vesting criteria, representing the right to receive shares of our common stock equal to </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$6.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">, based on a </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">30</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">-day weighted-average stock price as of December 15, 2014. Based on a Monte-Carlo valuation model, the fair value of the RSU was determined to be </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$2.4</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million, or </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">46.0%</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> of the grant price, which will be expensed on a straight-line basis over a derived service period of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">2.5</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> years, beginning in 2015.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 2133000 3067000 2833000 0.06 -0.08 0.06 -0.08 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt 12pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Earnings per Share</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt 12pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">Basic and diluted earnings per common share (&#x201C;EPS&#x201D;) is presented using the two-class method, which is an earnings allocation formula that determines earnings per share for common stock and any participating securities according to dividend rights and participation rights in undistributed earnings. Under the two-class method, EPS is computed by dividing the sum of distributed and undistributed earnings attributable to common stockholders by the weighted-average number of shares of common stock outstanding during the period. A participating security is a security that may participate in undistributed earnings with common stock had those earnings been distributed in any form. Our recently issued Series A convertible preferred stock (&#x201C;Series A preferred stock&#x201D;) represents participating securities as holders of the Series A preferred stock are entitled to receive any and all dividends declared or paid on common stock on an as-converted basis. In addition, shares of our non-vested restricted stock awards are considered participating securities as they represent unvested share-based payment awards containing non-forfeitable rights to dividends. As such, these participating securities must be included in the computation of EPS pursuant to the two-class method on a pro-rata, as-converted basis. Diluted EPS reflects the potential dilution from securities that could share in our earnings. In addition, the dilutive effect of each participating security is calculated using the more dilutive of the two-class method described above, which assumes that the securities remain in their current form, or the if-converted method, which assumes conversion to common stock as of the beginning of the reporting date. Anti-dilutive securities are excluded from diluted EPS. See </font><font style="display: inline;">Note 11&#x2014;Earnings Per Share</font><font style="display: inline;"> for further discussion.</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt 12pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">1</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">1</font><font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">. EARNINGS PER SHARE</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">The following table illustrates the basic and diluted earnings </font><font style="display: inline;">(loss) pe</font><font style="display: inline;">r share (&#x201C;EPS&#x201D;) computations for the </font><font style="display: inline;">three months end</font><font style="display: inline;">ed </font><font style="display: inline;">March</font><font style="display: inline;"> 31, 201</font><font style="display: inline;">5 and 2014</font><font <font style="display: inline;">For the three months ended </font><font style="display: inline;">March 31, 2015</font><font style="display: inline;"> and 201</font><font style="display: inline;">4</font><font style="display: inline;">, approximately </font><font style="display: inline;">2.3</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">1.5</font><font style="display: inline;"> million</font><font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;">options and RSUs, respectively, were not included in the calculation of diluted EPS as their effect would have been anti-dilutive. In addition to the antidilutive effects of options and RSUs, we did not assume the conversion of the </font><font style="display: inline;">Series A preferred stock </font><font style="display: inline;">into common shares for purposes of calculating diluted EPS as the effects would have been anti-dilutive. If converted, as of </font><font style="display: inline;">March 31, 2015, </font><font style="display: inline;">the Series A preferred stock would represent </font><font style="display: inline;">approximately </font><font style="display: inline;">15.2%</font><font style="display: inline;"> of our</font><font style="display: inline;"> common stock outstanding or </font><font style="display: inline;">13.8</font><font style="display: inline;"> million additional common shares. See </font><font style="display: inline;">Note 12 for f</font><font style="display: inline;">urther details regarding the preferred share offering.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;font-size:10pt;">Stock Repurchase Plan Authorizations</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">We continue to evaluate options to maximize the returns on our cash and maintain an appropriate capital structure, including, among other alternatives, repurchases </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">of our common stock. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">On December 26, 2013, our </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">board of directors (the &#x201C;Board&#x201D;)</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> approved the repurchase of up to </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$350.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million of our common stock. T</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">he number, price, structure and timing of the repu</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">rchases </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">will be at our sole discretion and future repurchases will be evaluated by us depending on market conditions, liquidity needs and other factors. Share repurchases may be made in the open market or in pri</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">vately negotiated transactions. </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">The repurchase authorization does not have an expiration date and does not oblige us to acquire any particular amount of our common </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">stock. Our Board may suspend, modify or terminate the repurchase program at any time without prior notice.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">During the </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">three months </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">ended </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">March</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> 31, 201</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">5</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">, we repurchased </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">approximately </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">1.7</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million shares</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> at a weighted-average </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">price of </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$11.60</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> per share for an aggregate price </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">of approximately </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">$20.0</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> million excluding</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> related commission charges under our publicly-an</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">no</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">unced repurchase plan. FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENTS</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Recurring Fair Value Measurements</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">A</font><font style="display: inline;">s of </font><font style="display: inline;">March 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014, our assets subject to fair value measurements consisted solely of cash equivalents of </font><font style="display: inline;">$13.0</font><font style="display: inline;"> million and </font><font style="display: inline;">$23.3</font><font style="display: inline;"> million, respectively.</font> </p> <p style="margin:12pt 0pt 6pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;font-style:italic;">Non-Recurring Fair Value Measurements</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt 18pt;border-bottom:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">The majority of our non-financial instruments, which include inventories, property and equipment and intangible assets, are not required to be carried at fair value on a recurring basis. However, if certain triggering events occur such that a non-financial instrument is required to be evaluated for impairment and the carrying value </font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">is not recoverable, the carrying value would be adjusted to the lower of its cost or fair value and an impairment charge would be recorde</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">d</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">. &nbsp;</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;">No</font><font style="display: inline;font-size:10pt;"> such charges were recorded for the three months ended March 31, 2015 or 2014.</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt 18pt;border-top:1pt none #D9D9D9 ;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 12pt"> <font style="display: inline;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p><font size="1"> </font></p> </div> </div> 78126000 4170000 4931000 62591000 5798000 636000 86014000 4170000 4713000 71815000 5026000 290000 175130000 4170000 6702000 157615000 5945000 698000 175101000 4170000 6114000 159357000 5026000 434000 97004000 1771000 95024000 147000 62000 89087000 1401000 87542000 144000 -2768000 494000 5708000 1751000 -1838000 -5723000 2044000 2227000 <div> <div style="margin-left:0pt;margin-right:0pt;"> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">3\. operations. INCOME TAXES</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;line-height:normal;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font> </p> <p style="margin:0pt 0pt 0pt 18pt;font-family:Times New Roman;font-size: 10pt"> <font style="display: inline;">During the three months ended </font><font style="display: inline;">March 31</font><font
